Participants.evidence: Patients who underwent an emergent (within 90 minutes) OR or IR procedure were included.

Method_Outcome.evidence: decreased time to hemostasis was associated with decreased mortality and decreased incidence of acute kidney injury (AKI), acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), multiple organ failure (MOF), sepsis, and venous thromboembolism (VTE).

Number_Randomised.evidence: Of 680 enrolled patients, 468 (69%) underwent an emergent procedure.

Number_Analysed.evidence: In 408 patients (87%) in whom hemostasis was achieved

Result_Outcome.evidence: every 15 minute decrease in time to hemostasis was associated with decreased 30-day mortality (RR 0.97, 95% CI 0.94–0.99), AKI (RR 0.97, 95% CI 0.96–0.98), ARDS (RR 0.98, 95% CI 0.97–0.99), MOF (RR 0.94, 95% CI 0.91–0.97), and sepsis (RR 0.98, 95% CI 0.96–0.99), but not VTE (RR 0.99, 95% CI 0.96–1.03).
